article.name: Slack Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.title: Slack Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.body:
In this guide, you’ll learn how to integrate Slack with SecurityCoach. You can use Slack to send real-time coaching notifications to your users when risky activity is detected on their devices.

For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Note:This integration will allow you to send real-time coaching notifications to your users. If you're looking for information about setting up security vendor integrations that will detect risky activity on your users' devices, see our other Setting Up Integrations articles.

Adding SecurityCoach to Slack

Before you can begin coaching your users in Slack, you must add SecurityCoach to your Slack workspace. To add SecurityCoach to Slack, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup.
  2. From the menu on the left side of the page, select Delivery Setup, then click Slack.
  3. Click the + Add to Slack button to open the Slack OAuth screen.
  4. Click Allow to grant SecurityCoach the needed permissions to view information and perform actions in Slack.

    The following Slack permission scopes are needed for the integration with SecurityCoach:
    • "chat:write"
    • "team:read"
    • "users:read"
    • "users:read.email”
    • "links.embed:write"
    • “links:write"
    • "links:read"
  5. Verify that the KB4-Security Awareness bot is now showing in your Slack Apps. To verify, log in to your Slack account, click Home from the sidebar on the left side of the page, then scroll down to the Apps section.

Syncing Slack Users with SecurityCoach

After you add SecurityCoach to Slack, your Slack team members will automatically be synced with SecurityCoach. The initial sync may take a few minutes to complete. After the initial sync, your Slack team members will be synced with SecurityCoach on a daily basis.

Sending Real-Time Coaching Notifications Using Slack

To coach your users in Slack, we recommend setting up a real-time coaching campaign. For more information, see our Real-Time Coaching Campaigns Guide.

Note:Phishing Security Tests (PSTs) from phishing campaigns cannot be sent using Slack.

Deleting a Slack Workspace Integration

To delete a Slack workspace integration from your SecurityCoach console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup.
  2. From the menu on the left side of the page, select Delivery Setup, then click Slack.
  3. Click the Delete button for the workspace that you want to delete.
  4. Confirm that you want to delete the workspace.
    Note:Deleting the Slack workspace will automatically revoke the authentication token for SecurityCoach.

images.alt:
This image displays an authorization request screen for a third-party application, **KnowBe4 SecurityCoach(US)**, seeking access to a **Slack workspace**.

**Overall Context and Header:**
The top section features the application's logo (an orange square with a white circular arrow) connected by a double-arrow icon to a blurred/redacted workspace icon.
The primary headline states: "**KnowBe4 SecurityCoach(US) is requesting permission to access the [Redacted Text] Slack workspace.**"

**Permissions Requested (Viewing Scopes):**
A section titled "**What will KnowBe4 SecurityCoach(US) be able to view?**" details the data read permissions. Each section is titled and accompanied by a relevant icon, and includes a dropdown indicator (▼).

1.  **Content and info about you** (Icon: Person silhouette):
    *   View information about your identity.
2.  **Content and info about channels & conversations** (Icon: Chat bubble):
    *   View video.training.knowbe4.com URLs in messages.
3.  **Content and info about your workspace** (Icon: Grid/App):
    *   View the name, email domain, and icon for workspaces KnowBe4 SecurityCoach(US) is connected to.
    *   View people in your workspace.
    *   View email addresses of people in your workspace.

**Permissions Requested (Action Scopes):**
A second section titled "**What will KnowBe4 SecurityCoach(US) be able to do?**" details the action/write permissions:

1.  **Perform actions in channels & conversations** (Icon: Chat bubble):
    *   Embed video.training.knowbe4.com video player URLs in messages and app surfaces.
    *   Send messages as **@kb4securityawareness**.
    *   Show previews of video.training.knowbe4.com URLs in messages.

This image is a screenshot of the "Delivery Setup" configuration page within an administrative application.

**UI Context and Navigation:**

1.  **Main Title:** The primary heading is "Delivery Setup."
2.  **Primary Navigation (Horizontal):** A tab bar contains links for Dashboard, Real-Time Coaching, Detection Rules, Catalog, Setup, and Reports. The **Setup** tab is highlighted as active.
3.  **Secondary Navigation (Vertical):** A left sidebar displays sub-sections: Security Integrations, User Mapping Setup, Mapping Recommendations, and **Delivery Setup**. The **Delivery Setup** link is highlighted in blue, indicating the active page context.

**Main Content Area:**

The content area repeats the title "Delivery Setup" and provides an instructional note: "Configure delivery channels for your SecurityCoach notifications."

Three integration cards are displayed, each showing a configured notification channel:

1.  **Slack:** Displaying the Slack logo and text. Status is indicated by a green checkmark and the green text: "Configured."
2.  **Microsoft Teams:** Displaying the Microsoft Teams logo and text. Status is indicated by a green checkmark and the green text: "Configured."
3.  **Email:** Displaying an @ symbol and the text "Email." Status is indicated by a green checkmark and the green text: "Configured."

All three potential delivery channels (Slack, Microsoft Teams, and Email) are currently shown as fully configured.
